text: Patient: It was in September, late September. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Doin’ good! Doctor: Uh, what’s goin’ on? Jaw still troubling you? Patient: A little bit, yeah. It’s, it’s, uh, right, right in, um in here. Right here. And the teeth are a little bit sensitive, just in spots Doctor: Gotten better or gotten worse? Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller?

text: Patient: DOD? Doctor: Yeah, the DOD. Patient: Wow. Doctor: I know; a lot of people are surprised. And this was a grant where the DOD wanted to fund a project that would a small benefit or have a transformative benefit. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In other words a pretty huge benefit. And they were also looking for things that were paradigm shifts. In other words that runs against the grain. And so one of my colleagues from H___ applied for this grant. His name is Dr. ___. He was the mastermind behind this approach. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: He was awarded a grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So because it was a transformative impact grant, we decided to call the trial the Transformer Trial. So this is a study where we’re testing this high-dose testosterone therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah.

Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy.

text: Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her. Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
